reqwire.helpers¶

Various helper utilities.

reqwire.helpers.cli.emojize(message, **kwargs)[source]¶

Wrapper around emoji.emojize() for Windows compatibility.

Emoji are not well supported under Windows. This function not only checks sys.platform, but the file /proc/version as well to prevent “emojification” on the Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL, otherwise known as Ubuntu on Windows).

Parameters:
  • message – The format string. See emoji.emojize() for more information. Any emoji placeholders will be removed if Windows or WSL are detected.
  • **kwargs – Passed to emoji.emojize().

reqwire.helpers.requirements¶

Helpers for managing Python package requirements.

reqwire.helpers.requirements.build_ireq_set(specifiers, index_urls=None, resolve_canonical_names=True, resolve_versions=True, sort_specifiers=True)[source]¶

Builds a set of install requirements.

Parameters:
  • specifiers – A list of specifier strings.
  • index_urls – List of Python package indexes. Only used if resolve_canonical_names or resolve_versions is True.
  • resolve_canonical_names – Queries package indexes provided by index_urls for the canonical name of each specifier. For example, flask will get resolved to Flask.
  • resolve_versions – Queries package indexes for latest package versions.
  • sort_specifiers – Sorts specifiers alphabetically.
Returns:

A set of HashableInstallRequirement.
reqwire.helpers.requirements.get_canonical_name(package_name, index_urls=None, *args)[source]¶

Returns the canonical name of the given Python package.

Parameters:
  • package_name – The package name.
  • index_urls – A list of Python package indexes.
  • *args – Command-line options and arguments passed to pip.
Returns:

The canonical name of a package, or None if no packaging could be found in the given search indexes.
class reqwire.helpers.requirements.HashableInstallRequirement(req, comes_from, source_dir=None, editable=False, link=None, as_egg=False, update=True, pycompile=True, markers=None, isolated=False, options=None, wheel_cache=None, constraint=False)[source]¶

A hashable version of pip.req.InstallRequirement.

classmethod from_ireq(ireq)[source]¶

Builds a new instance from an existing install requirement.

reqwire.helpers.requirements.parse_requirements(filename, *args)[source]¶

Parses a requirements source file.

Parameters:
  • filename – The requirements source filename.
  • *args – Command-line options and arguments passed to pip.
Returns:

A set of pip.req.InstallRequirement, and a pip.index.PackageFinder instance.
class reqwire.helpers.requirements.PyPiHtmlParser(search=None, *args, **kwargs)[source]¶

An HTML parse for Python package indexes.

class reqwire.helpers.requirements.PyPiHtmlParserState[source]¶

An enumeration of parsing states for PyPiHtmlParser.

collecting_package_name = <PyPiHtmlParserState.collecting_package_name: 1>¶

The state indicating a package anchor tag is being visited.

found_package_name = <PyPiHtmlParserState.found_package_name: 2>¶

The state indicating a package matching a search was visited.

waiting = <PyPiHtmlParserState.waiting: 0>¶

The default parser state.

class reqwire.helpers.requirements.RequirementFile(filename, requirements=None, nested_cfiles=None, nested_rfiles=None, index_urls=None)[source]¶

Represents a Python requirements.txt file.

extra_index_urls¶

Extra Python package index URLs.

index_url¶

A Python package index URL.

parse(*args)[source]¶

Parses a requirements file.

Parameters:*args – Command-line options and arguments passed to pip.
Returns:A set of requirements, index URLs, nested constraint files, and nested requirements files.

The nested constraint and requirements files are sets of RequirementFile instances.
parse_nested_files()[source]¶

Parses a requirements file, looking for nested files.

Returns:A set of constraint files and requirements files.
reload()[source]¶

Reloads the current requirements file.

reqwire.helpers.requirements.resolve_ireqs(requirements, prereleases=False, intersect=False, *args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Resolves install requirements with piptools.

Parameters:
  • requirements – An iterable of pip.req.InstallRequirement.
  • prereleases – Whether or not to include prereleases.
  • intersect – Return only install requirements that intersect with requirements. Default behavior is to include the entire dependency graph as produced by piptools.
  • *args – Command-line options and arguments passed to pip.
  • **kwargs – Passed to piptools.resolver.Resolver.
Returns:

A set of pip.req.InstallRequirement.
reqwire.helpers.requirements.resolve_specifier(specifier, prereleases=False, *args)[source]¶

Resolves the given specifier.

Parameters:
  • specifier – A specifier string.
  • prereleases – Whether or not to include prereleases.
  • *args – Command-line options and arguments passed to pip.
Returns:

A set of pip.req.InstallRequirement.
reqwire.helpers.requirements.update_ireq_name(install_requirement, package_name)[source]¶

Updates the name of an existing install requirement.

Parameters:
  • install_requirement – A pip.req.InstallRequirement instance.
  • package_name – The new package name.
Returns:

The install_requirement with mutated requirement name.
reqwire.helpers.requirements.write_requirements(filename, requirements, index_url=None, extra_index_urls=None, header=None)[source]¶

Writes install requirements to a file.

Note that this function is destructive and will overwrite any existing files.

Parameters:
  • filename – The output filename.
  • requirements – An iterable of pip.req.InstallRequirement.
  • index_url – The primary Python package index URL.
  • extra_index_urls – Extra package index URLs.
  • header – A header string to prepend to the file.

reqwire.config¶

Provides configuration and configuration defaults.

reqwire.errors¶

Provides custom exception classes.

exception reqwire.errors.IndexUrlMismatchError[source]¶

Indicates a conflict between CLI and requirement source file.

exception reqwire.errors.ReqwireError[source]¶

Base class for all exceptions thrown by reqwire.

reqwire.scaffold¶

Scaffold supporting files and directories.

reqwire.scaffold.build_filename(working_directory, tag_name, extension='.in', prefix='src')[source]¶

Constructs a path to a tagged requirement source file.

Parameters:
  • working_directory – The parent directory of the source file.
  • tag_name – The tag name.
  • extension – The file extension. Defaults to .in.
  • prefix – The subdirectory under the working directory to create the source file in. Defaults to src.
reqwire.scaffold.build_source_header(format_string='# Generated by reqwire on %c\n{nested_cfiles}{nested_rfiles}{index_url}{extra_index_urls}\n', index_url=None, extra_index_urls=None, nested_cfiles=None, nested_rfiles=None, timestamp=None)[source]¶

Builds a header for requirement source file.

Parameters:
  • format_string – A format string containing one or more of the following keys: nested_cfiles, nested_rfiles, index_url, and extra_index_urls. The format string may also include strftime formatting directives.
  • index_url – A Python package index URL.
  • extra_index_urls – Extra Python package index URLs.
  • nested_cfiles – A set of nested constraint files.
  • nested_rfiles – A set of nested requirement files.
  • timestamp – A datetime.datetime object. If not provided, defaults to the current datetime.
Returns:

The rendered header string.
reqwire.scaffold.DEFAULT_HEADER = '# Generated by reqwire on %c\n{nested_cfiles}{nested_rfiles}{index_url}{extra_index_urls}\n'¶

The default header format string for requirement source files.

reqwire.scaffold.extend_source_file(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Adds requirements to an existing requirement source file.

Parameters:
  • working_directory – The parent directory of the source file.
  • tag_name – The tag name.
  • specifiers – A list of specifiers.
  • extension – The file extension. Defaults to .in.
  • index_url – A Python package index URL.
  • extra_index_urls – Extra Python package index URLs.
  • lookup_index_urls – Python package index URLs used to search for packages during resolving. This parameter is only useful if an attempt is made to add packages found only in indexes that are only specified in nested requirement source files.
  • resolve_canonical_names – Queries package indexes provided by index_urls for the canonical name of each specifier. For example, flask will get resolved to Flask.
  • resolve_versions – Queries package indexes for latest package versions.
reqwire.scaffold.init_source_dir(working_directory, mode=511, create_parents=True, exist_ok=False, name='src')[source]¶

Creates a requirements source directory.

Parameters:
  • working_directory – The parent directory of the source file.
  • mode – Permissions with which to create source file. Defaults to 0o777.
  • create_parents – Whether or not parent directories should be created if missing.
  • exist_ok – Does not raise an OSError if directory creation failed.
  • name – The name of the subdirectory to create under the working directory. Defaults to src.
reqwire.scaffold.init_source_file(working_directory, tag_name, extension='.in', index_url=None, extra_index_urls=None, encoding=None, errors=None, mode=438, overwrite=False)[source]¶

Creates a requirements source file.

Parameters:
  • working_directory – The requirements working directory.
  • tag_name – The tag name.
  • extension – The file extension. Defaults to ”.in”.
  • index_url – Base URL of Python package index.
  • extra_index_urls – Iterable of URLs of secondary package indexes.
  • encoding – Passed to io.open() when creating source file.
  • errors – Passed to io.open() when creating source file.
  • mode – Permissions with which to create source file. Defaults to 0o666.
  • overwrite – Whether or not to overwrite an existing source file.
Returns:

Path to source file.
